page.title: 01GENERAL SURVEY OF LANDSCAPE
page.content: The area is north of Paisley and is part of the Scottish midlands. The land is flat, low-lying floodplain drained by the rivers Gryfe and Black Cart Water. Broom Hill(36m)is the highest point, and to the north. The area is mainly agricultural. There are intensive dairy farms due to mild, wet climate and deep, fertile soils giving good quality grass and high milk yields for the large urban markets nearby. The M8, A726 and B790 are the main roads which pass through the area. A British Rail railway line also passes through the area. Glasgow airport occupies land in the easternmost square. The airport is the major employer in the area. Road widening and the new Barnsford Bridge are under construction. Woodland to W and NW occupies about 8% of the area.
